overview: From 2025-09-28 to 2025-10-05, ethereum-optimism/optimism had 40 new PRs (38 merged), 16 new issues, and 53 active contributors.

topIssues.title: L2CL<>L2EL: Find out condition of L2EL for starting EL Syncing
topIssues.author: pcw109550
topIssues.body:
Find out the condition of EL that EL is able to EL Sync. This may differ by node implementations/networks and first priority is op-geth with op-sepolia.

We need this because when we do multiple EL Sync, we need to make the EL be able to EL Sync again.

Some artifacts(not confirmed):
> op-geth must not have finalized block to trigger EL Sync(snap sync).

Necessary for removal of ReqRes Sync to EL Sync. Must understand the starting conditions of EL Sync to rely on it.

This is out of date

General tracking for features proposed to be included in the Isthmus upgrade.

### Other features

- [x] https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs/issues/511

## Probably NGMI this time

- [x] #12435
- [ ] [Deposit Queue](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs/pull/82)
- [ ] [Decouple block times between L1 and L2 (or L2 and L3)](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs/issues/416)

---
NB - the above is all subject to further discussion and agreement; nothing is set in stone just yet. But we are no longer taking further submissions for Isthmus (unless they are extraordinarily important).

topIssues.title: enable flashblocks on op-mainnet
topIssues.author: yashvardhan-kukreja
topIssues.body:
After having thorough confidence on flashblocks-enablement on op-sepolia, we can proceed with enabling flashblocks on op-mainnet.

This can be done in a progressive manner with one sequencer at a time with dry_run mode.

A/C:
- op-mainnet passing Flashblocks + Regular RRC
- monitoring and alerting baked in into the existing setup to cover flashblocks related alerts.

Blocked on https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/16497

topIssues.title: op-node: split CLI/entrypoint/service/backend
topIssues.author: protolambda
topIssues.body:
Split the op-node setup to better encapsulate the separate layers of service framework:
- CLI: CLI definition, urfave etc.
- entrypoint: turns CLI into config, returns service as CLI lifetime
- service: manages peripherals (metrics, pprof, rpc servers), and inner backend
- backend: business logic of the actual node

topIssues.title: deploy flashblocks-rpc node
topIssues.author: yashvardhan-kukreja
topIssues.body: Deploy two flashblocks-rpc serving flashblocks-rpc as per this reference: https://docs.base.org/base-chain/flashblocks/apps

Differences from #17465:

- has a single struct per Safe.

topPRs.title: op-node,op-program,kona: embed L1ChainConfig in configuration
topPRs.author: geoknee
topPRs.body:
Since [Ecotone](https://specs.optimism.io/protocol/ecotone/l1-attributes.html), the L1BlockInfo deposit transaction couples the L2 state transition with the blob base fee of the l1 origin. The blob base fee is not part of the block, but rather computed from `block.excessBlobGas` with an [off-chain formula which varies according to which fork is active on L1.](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth/blob/51614a3dc4af4a2b503ba178e0799013e6774613/consensus/misc/eip4844/eip4844.go#L180-L197)

For the L2 state to accurately reflect the blob base fee of the l1 origin, it is necessary to provide the L2 consensus client information about the fork schedule of the L1 which it derives from.

This PR does that in a relatively lightweight way:
* for chains with a recognized l1 chain ID (such as all chains in the superchain registry), lookup the l1 chain config (either for Mainnet or Sepolia) using op-geth as a library. This information needs to be kept updated as new L1 forks (including BPO or blob parameter only forks) are scheduled in upstream geth and brought in through upstream merges. When this happens, we need to update the absolute prestate for the proofs system
* for custom chains (think devnets, test environments, chains which are not in the superchain registry) it is required to pass the l1 chain config via a new CLI flag. This can be directly JSON encoded or embedded in a `genesis.json` file.
* Does something similar for the op-program, which does not allow information to be passed at runtime but instead via filesystem embedding
* Also includes changes in this direction for kona

I avoided embedding the l1 chain config inside the `rollup.Config`, as that would require changing all of the data in the superchain registry.

This is a backwards compatible change which also makes the derivation pipeline compatible with post-Fusaka L1s.

The diff is quite large, mostly because there is a lot of boilerplate to change both in production and test code.

Closes #17493

topPRs.title: feat: add EL engine mocking support to op-sync-tester
topPRs.author: avorylli
topPRs.body:
## Summary
Implements support for mocking different EL (Execution Layer) implementations in op-sync-tester to validate L2CL behavior with various engine types.

## Changes
- Add `EngineBehavior` interface for different EL implementations (Geth, Reth, Erigon)
- Support engine-specific behaviors around sync modes and post-finalization EL sync
- Add configuration fields: `engine_kind`, `sync_mode`, `network_type`
- Implement network-specific characteristics (regenesis support, block times)
- Add comprehensive test coverage for new functionality

## Engine Differences
- **Geth**: Conservative sync, no post-finalization EL sync support
- **Reth**: Aggressive sync, supports post-finalization EL sync
- **Erigon**: Optimized for archival data, supports post-finalization EL sync

## Testing
- All existing tests pass
- New test coverage: 30.4% backend, 90% config, 100% types
- Race detector clean
- Linter clean

Fixes #17632

- it manages a heap of unsafe blocks received over p2p
- it tries to apply the highest block number payload
